titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nikolai Nadezhin Papers
titlestmt.author: by Paul C. Allen

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:31

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers contain letters to and from Nadezhin regarding social engagements, manuscript submissions, and requests for performances. The bulk of the correspondence consists of letters from Bryher discussing Nadezhin's work, literature in general, and personal matters. The collection also contains drafts of Nadezhin's articles, poetry, and autobiography, as well as biographical information, concert programs, and photographs.

langmaterial.language: Letters are in English, Russian, and Italian and some of the poetry manuscripts are in Russian.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Papers were acquired by Yale University as a gift from Bryher in 1963.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Nikolai Nadezhin Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Nikolai Nadezhin Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Restricted Fragile Papers in boxes 5-6 may only be consulted with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies for reference use have been substituted in the main files. Those in Box 6 are oversize newspaper or magazine clippings.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Slavic names, titles, and quotations in their original languages have been transliterated in accordance with Library of Congress guidelines.

bioghist.head: NIKOLAI ALEXANDROVICH NADEZHIN (1885-1959)
bioghist.p: Nikolai Alexandrovich Nadezhin (also known as Nicholas Nadejine) was born on March 9, 1885 to a well-established family of the intelligentsia. His grandfather was Nikolai Petrovich Makarov, the lexicographer responsible for the first complete Russian/French dictionary. Nadezhin's early years were spent at the small ancestral manor called Funicovo near Tula where he was sent to be raised by his grandfather.

After matriculating from the "gymnasium" in 1905, Nadezhin began his first year at Moscow University, where he became a member of the Socialist Revolutionary Party and was soon involved in revolutionary activities. Early in 1906, Nadezhin was responsible for the armed hold-up of a local newspaper in order to produce a half million printed copies of the "Vyborg Manifesto." Later that year he was arrested and sentenced to life exile in Siberia, but managed to escape from captivity to Europe in 1908, never again to return to Russia. Eventually Nadezhin made his way to Italy and then to Capri.

In October 1918 Nadezhin met Compton Mackenzie, who owned a nearby villa on Capri. "Monty" Mackenzie invited Nadezhin, whom he nicknamed "Bim," to his villa as his guest. Nadezhin soon became the lover of Compton's wife, Faith Compton Mackenzie, and remained at the villa as her companion, with the complete knowledge of her husband, until 1922.

Between 1922 and 1938 Nadezhin lived in Australia, New Zealand, England and America, traveling with Russian emigrant theatrical groups as an opera singer. He wrote poetry in both Russian and English, and had three books published: Razuvieren'e (1925); Izbrannyia stikhotvoreniia (1954); and Knizhnaia Polka (1955). In 1927 he married a young Australian girl, Therese-Helen-Lydia Tritton, at the Russian Orthodox Church in London. Following Nadezhin's alleged affair with Mrs. Vera Oppenheimer, the couple were divorced in 1936. Two years later Lydia married the last Prime Minister of the Russian Provisory Government (1917), Alexandr Fyodorovich Kerensky, whom she had met through Nadezhin. That same year Nadezhin returned to Faith and helped her to move to Peace Close, a cottage in Somerset, after the sale of the villa in Capri. Nadezhin cared for Faith through her various illnesses and provided material for her writing for the rest of his life.

Sometime in the early 1940s Nadezhin met Bryher and soon began submitting his poems to her. Through their correspondence they developed a friendship that was to last until Nadezhin's death. During World War II Nadezhin served for a time as an interpreter for the British forces. Following the war, he joined the Russian Service of the British Broadcasting Corporation as a correspondent and worked in the War Office of the British government as well as other odd jobs. During the mid-1950s he assisted Compton Mackenzie with the publication of The Gramophone Monthly Review , contributing articles on Russian composers. Nadezhin died in the summer of 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Nikolai Nadezhin Papers consist primarily of manuscript writings and a small body of correspondence, spanning the years years 1910-1958. The Nadezhin Papers are divided into three series: Correspondence (Box 1), Writings (Boxes 2-3), and Personal Papers (Box 4).

Series I, Correspondence
, includes letters to and from Nadezhin, dated between 1910 and 1958. This correspondence is arranged alphabetically within thirty-one incoming letter files, including one file of collective letters (postcards and holiday greetings signed by three or more people), one file of unidentified letters, and two files of third-party correspondence. The letters are written in Russian, Italian, and English and deal with manuscript submissions, requests for performances, and personal matters.

The bulk of the correspondence consists of the over 120 letters from Bryher, covering the period 1944-58. These letters discuss Nadezhin's poetry, Compton and Faith MacKenzie, Bryher's financial assistance to Nadezhin, personal matters, and the latest books they have read. Nadezhin's letters to Bryher are housed in the Bryher Papers. Other important correspondents are Gebby Katz, a woman with whom Nadezhin had an affair in 1914, and Faith Compton Mackenzie.

Series II, Writings
, is divided into subseries of Prose Works , Poetry , Translations , and Writings of Others . Prose Works consists of fifteen folders of typescripts for his autobiography, entitled variously "Apology of an Iconoclast," "Apology of an Outsider," or "Lest I Forget," and eleven folders of short articles on Pushkin, Russian poetry, Nadezhin's travels, and printed reviews of Nadezhin's works. The autobiography covers the period 1889 through 1906 and describes Nadezhin's involvement with the Socialist Revolutionary Party in the Russian Revolution of 1905 and his subsequent exile to Siberia.
Poetry consists of nine folders of Nadezhin's poems in Russian and English, one folder of unidentified poems, a published book of poetry, Izbrannia stikhotvoreniia , with a dedicatory poem to Bryher, and a review of his book of poems, Knizhnaia Polka . Translations contains one folder of poems by Rupert Brooke, Edmund Blunden, Walter De La Mare, Vita Sackville West, and Osbert Sitwell translated into Russian by Nadezhin. Works of Others is devoted to poems, translations, and articles by authors other than Nadezhin, including translations of poems by Pushkin, Lermontov, and Wolkonski, and a printed article by Sir Compton Mackenzie.

Series III, Personal Papers
, consists of biographical material, photographs, concert programs from Nadezhin's performances, and miscellaneous material. The biographical material contains contracts, press releases, marriage and divorce certificates, and a photostat of a biographical note about Nadezhin written by Nina Berberova for Norman Holmes Pearson. The photographs are primarily of Nadezhin and members of his family between 1908 and 1928, with a few pictures of Sir Compton Mackenzie and Faith Compton Mackenzie. The concert programs date from 1913 to 1928. Box 4, folder 83 contains miscellaneous material, mostly undated, including a silhouette portrait of Bryher, magazine clippings, and a typescript copy of Peter the Great's will.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence is divided into two subseries: Nadezhin Correspondence and Third-Party Correspondence . All letters in Nadezhin Correspondence are incoming except for one letter to Faith Compton Mackenzie, February 16, 1941. The correspondence is arranged alphabetically by surname. Collective letters and unidentified correspondence are placed at the end of the subseries. Third-Party Correspondence consists of third party letters to Faith Compton MacKenzie, Lydia (Tritton) Nadezhin, and others.

p.ref: See also: Betty Sandburg, Box 1, folder 22

did.unittitle: Russian Embassy, Rome: certificate of Nadezhin's government service from February 16-March 1, 1917

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings, is divided into the alpha- betically arranged subseries Prose Works , Poetry , Translations , and Works of Others . Within the subseries Poetry the poems are arranged by title or first line.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Personal Papers, consists of chronologically arranged biographical information on Nadezhin, concert programs, photographs, and miscellaneous papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxes 5 and 6, Restricted Fragile Papers, contain fragile originals. Box 6 houses oversize papers. The material is arranged in folder order separately in both Box 5 and Box 6. It may only be seen with the permission of the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
